comment_text:
FAQ:
1. This is similar to the Magnus effect in that the relative motion of a spinning ball through fluid creates a force that affects its motion. It's different in that here the fluid starts the ball spinning and there is an equilibrium point around which there are restoring forces. In the Magnus effect the ball must be spinning to begin with and since the fluid is everywhere it can continually change speed and direction.
2. It's not the Coanda effect. The Coanda effect relies on entraining fluid from the surrounding area creating a region of low pressure. Here there is no water surrounding the stream to entrain (since it is a narrow stream).
3. Adhesion between the water and the ball is important - this is what directs the water flow over the ball.
4. The sum of the forces I show should not be zero but equal and opposite to the weight of the ball. Hence the forces of up and out from the initial contact with the stream and up and in from the spray add to make an upward force equal to weight (the in part of the second force is much more important than the up part)
5. It would be interesting to try this with a hydrophobic coating and see if it still works. My hypothesis is it would be much harder.
6. Apparently there are other fountains and toys that use this principle that I was unaware of. This video uses the design created by my friend Blake.

Hi Derek. I'm a bit late to the party, but I only just saw this video. Your explanation makes sense (conservation of momentum as the water leaves the ball) but I'm not so sure that the Coanda effect doesn't play a part... I think it's possible that the levitation happens because you have flow over the surface of the ball, which entrains surrounding air, generating a low pressure region where the water stays attached to the ball. Some water separates as it travels with the ball. The separation of water disrupts the entrainment of the surrounding air so the local pressure reduces compared to the start. When you integrate the pressure over the whole surface, you end up with a net force up and towards the stream. Similarly, you can take a piece of paper, hold it vertically and move it towards a running tap. As soon as it touches the water, the paper bends more towards the water. When the tap is running without the paper, air is still entrained but from all sides so the water runs straight down as it's in equilibrium. When the paper is placed with one side towards the stream and touching the stream, the dry side has no entrained air by the stream, only the wet side resulting in a low pressure and a net horizontal force further towards the stream. Try this out :) (maybe with a laminated paper, cause the paper gets soaked very quickly otherwise and stops working).

I'm not quite sure about your explanation.  The water separating from the ball wouldn't exert an upward force on the ball once the rotation matched the speed of the water.  Looking at the trajectory of water as it leaves the surface makes that clear.  It's possible that water on the surface of the ball creates drag as it spins around but that wouldn't be enough to offset the pressure from the upward stream.  I suspect that the weight of the water relative to the weight of the styrofoam is key to why this works.  It's likely the center of gravity of the sphere is changing with one side being impregnated with water and the other where the water is separating from the surface.  The drag at separation in combination with an offset center of gravity seems like a better explanation.

The upward force of the water jet is opposed by the weight of the ball (gravity). If the ball falls down closer towards the water jet, the force of the water on it in the vertical direction will increase. The ball will fall until it reaches a point where the force is great enough to push it back upwards, where it will immediately fall again as the force on it decreases, thus creates a self-stabilizing loop in the vertical direction.

Because the jet hits the ball at an angle it also imparts a small side-ways force on the ball which would push the ball out of the stream if not opposed by some other force. This opposing force is the magnus effect due to the balls rotation. The further the ball moves out of the stream, the more angular momentum will be imparted on the ball, due to the angle of impact from the water jet, therefore increasing the spin and therefore increasing magnus force, pushing it back towards the stream, thus creating a self-stabilizing loop in the horizontal direction.

That's my take on it.
The rotation with the flow leads to reduced flow separation allowing the fluid to "cling" to the sphere momentarily. As it is rejected from the sphere an equal and opposite force keeps it in place.

I disagree with your hypothesis that the water being thrown off the bottom is the main factor causing the ball to remain stable. For that to be the case there would need to be a much larger fraction of the original stream being redirected by the balls rotation. I believe that Bernoulli's principle is the main factor. As the stream contacts the ball, the stream is squashed/flattened which causes the stream to increase speed therefore lowering pressure, creating a pulling force. Laminar flow around the whole ball is not required, this is demonstrated by the simple ping pong ball on a string experiment, when the ball contacts a stream of water from a tap, the ball will be attracted to the flow immediately on contact before it gets encased in water. And if your stream is small enough you will reach an equilibrium point where the is barely any contact between the ball and water but the ball remains stuck against the flow.

I watched through the slow motion footage of you cutting the stream with your hand and if you watch carefully you should notice that just as the stream re-contacts the ball, before any of the water flies over and down, the ball gets 'pulled' in towards the stream. I believe this is further evidence that Bernoulli's principle is playing a major part.

This is because of Friction, Coanda effect followed by Magnus effect.

In the middle, he also showed how the water followed the curve of the ball. This is mainly because of 'Coanda effect'.

From Wikipedia,

The tendency of a jet of fluid emerging from an orifice to follow an adjacent flat or curved surface and to entrain fluid from the surroundings so that a region of lower pressure develops.
Here, the water is trying to entrain fluid from surroundings. When it comes near to a surface, it cannot pull air from surroundings which makes a low-pressure region between surface and jet. This is because, 'when something is emptied from its place, then something should fill the void to keep the balance.'

Firstly, the ball starts to rotate because of the friction between water and ball surface which is just like a Tesla turbine. As the ball is being hit by the water on one side (not centre), it will push the ball to the other side because it comes in the way of the water. Once the ball starts rotating, the fluid following the surface don't adhere to the surface much longer and drift apart tangentially.

This is where the 'Magnus effect' kicks in. The magnus effect creates a force perpendicular to the jet direction. This force pushes back the ball to remain in contact with the jet on one side. So, the weight of the rotating ball is born by the jet completely.

The magnus force is proportional to the speed of rotation of the ball which is proportional to the velocity of the jet of water.

So, the ball levitates in air as long as the jet discharge is kept constant.

G'day Mate, This was a really interesting video for me except I thought I would point out that the reason this phenomenon happens is because of the Coander effect. NOT BECAUSE THE WATER CREATES AND EQUAL AND OPPOSITE REACTION.

You can look it up and there are some great demonstrations of this effect on YouTube using a spoon and a running tap. Basically, when a fluid flows over a convex surface, it has a tendency to stick to the surface and suck the surface towards the stream. This also applies to plane wings (because air is considered a fluid in physics) when the plane wing moves forward. The air attaches itself to the wing sucking the wing upward. If you don't quite get it then just search up Coander effect with spoon and any video will do. It's quite interesting to see what happens.

Thanks for your time and the video! Cheers, Tim

This is a special case.  The necessary condition is the high surface area with respect to the mass,  It should work with anything circular in cross section.  The zone of stability is between 45 and 135 degrees. Those points reflect the maximum horizontal forces inside the system If no perturbing forces push the center of gravity from between those two points it will stay there as long as your water holds out.  Gravity provides the restoring force.  The forces are radial across the top and the spray is momentum.  The radial forces across the top sum to a vector equal and opposing the resultant vector of the stream, after removing the couple which rotates the ball.  The ball bobbing in the videos is a.response to variations in the stream and the wind load.  The restoring force at work. The heavy lifting in the phenomena is done by symmetry.  A sphere is placed in the right position to achieve this effect because it is symmetric about all three axis.  It can't be inserted incorrectly  A disc has to be placed at the center line.  Place it off center and there are no restoring forces and the disc will wobble and fall off. The water uses the ball to create a mass pump.  You provide the energy to kick off the process by placing the ball.  This doesn't scale well obviously.  And you can't approach the stable point from the center, the flow will accelerate the ball from the stream.  The effect looks strange because we aren't use to seeing very small effects generate visible phenomena like this.

The most important part of how this works the Bernoulli effect, don't be so quick to discount that part of this system. Just like blowing air between two balloons makes them touch, shooting water past the side of a sphere/disc "sucks" it towards the stream while the force of the stream colliding with the disc provides force up (against gravity) and in the opposite direction of the sucking force (yes, I understand that there's no such thing as sucking just like there's no such thing as coldness), hence the stable configuration. The only reason you can't achieve the same with a hairdryer is because they can't move air fast enough, you can achieve a similar levitation with an air compressor and a radially-symmetrical object.

Hey Veritasium - thinking about an alternate explanation for this (or maybe just another affect helping the equilibrium) and wondering what you think:
The upward force of the water counteracts the downward force of gravity holding the ball at a fixed height set by the water's speed (since the speed of the water itself is a function of its height). The water forces the ball to one side, but it causes the ball to rotate about the point of contact with the stream of water, not about the center of the ball. Because the ball rotates about the point of contact, that would cause the center of the mass of the ball to move toward the stream of water, helping keep it in place even though the edge is being pushed away.
Let me know what you think - I know a lot more about rigid-body dynamics than fluid mechanics, so this explanation is how I rationalized what I was seeing before you offered your explanation.

I don't agree with the explanation in the video. My theory is as follows: the main two forces keeping the ball in place are:
- pushing effect of the water stream hitting the ball (this also provides skewed force away from the stream)
- pulling effect of the water as it bounces (this also provides skewed force towards the stream). Keep in mind, water is fairly "sticky" with fairly high density. So as it exits the impact, it pulls the ball in the direction it is travelling. Majority of water exits the impact in a way that it pulls the ball into the water. The minority of water exits the impact away from the stream and is actually creating a small instability, as opposed to stability (explained in the video).

Issue: The concept of the water applying an inward force when the water is "ejected" is confusing. Would not the centripetal force of cohesion would be pulling the ball the ball outward? Now when it is "ejected" that centripetal force of cohesion is no longer strong enough to keep the water adhered to the surface so the water is "ejected". The loss of an outward force is not an inward force...

EX: If I have an object on a string and spin it, it applies tension to the string (pulling outward). If I let go the object is "ejected" but I have let go so it can no longer exert force on me AND its a string so it wouldn't be able to apply a compressive force effectively either.

Theory 1, Difference in centripetal force F=ma: If the acceleration a=rw^2 is treated as constant around the ball such that the only variable in the force is the adhered mass of water then... There would be more mass on the stream side then the free side. This greater mass on the stream side would result in a greater centripetal force that would "pull" the ball towards the stream" (a perpendicular force)

As the ball accelerates the mass decreases on the free side of ball more so then the top or back side so the difference in centripetal force pulling outward is greater. this would pull the ball back to the stream.

Theory 2, shear acceleration: When the ball rotation ally accelerates or decelerates it applies a sheer force to water adhered to the surface. This force would be tangential to the surface of the ball. Such that when the ball accelerates as it moves out of the stream the water adhered to the surface on the top of the ball is accelerated away from the stream this would require the water exert an opposite force on the ball "pushing" the ball back towords the stream.

Disclaimer: The theory have about 30 minutes of thought done while drive, no math was applied. I just don't like the concept of the water "pushing" inward on the sphere.

From conservation of momentum we can see that the water sprayed around has a total momentum of 0 parallel to the ground (the perpendicular component is constantly increasing due to gravity). Therefore, due to the steam not hitting the ball right in the middle there is a torque created which is compensated by the torque of the water sprayed in a spiral. The surface of the ball is moving slightly slower than the stream of water so the water is slowed down which causes the torque on the ball. If the ball moves away from the stream the ball accelerates which breaks the balance of the horizontal momentum of the water and the water accelerated by the top of the ball loses less speed so it ejects earlier and less water is thrown from the bottom of the ball and at the same time the water reflected from the ball is reflected at a smaller angle so the two effects added together cause this unbalanced momentum and push the ball towards the stream. When the ball moves too close to the stream both of these effects are reversed which causes the ball to move away from the stream. Most of the upwards force on the ball is caused by the impact of the stream and the rest is from the water turning to the side and over by the attraction of the ball. There is almost no water accelerated upwards by the ball so there is no significant downwards force caused by this so the other effects are balanced by the gravitational pull of the ball by the planet.

The water stream emerging from the hose has upwards momentum which acts in the opposite direction to the force of gravity. Because water is viscous, the water particles stick to the surface of the ball (making the water's velocity on the surface of the ball stationary relative to the ball). This is known as the no-slip condition and it's what generates the spin on the ball.

The flow isn't always purely laminar. With a larger ball and a faster moving stream it will become inherently more turbulent yet it will still make the ball levitate. The sentence at 1:40 or so implies that the water is attached to the surface of the ball better when it is not turbulent, but that's not true. I think the reason the larger ball moves around so much is because it is shedding vortices. The Foppl vortices that you can see in the wake of the smaller ball tell you that if you increase the flow velocity or the ball's diameter some more, it will begin to vortex shed because these two point vortices become unstable at higher Reynolds numbers.

You claim there is a return force. I disagree.

The fact that the water is carried over and falls off the other side of the ball is not an indication that the water is forcing the ball back to where it was. That is what you thought. That isn't the case.

I am pretty sure what is going on has to do with water bonding with the ball and the suction effect it creates upon bonding. You know this bonding from the popping noise when a ball sits in your pool and you yank it out, for example.

So what is actually happening is, the water shoots by and some of the water creates a contact point where the water and the ball are now bound. Much like a vacuum.
The water, still having momentum, tries to carry the ball up with it. But the ball is too heavy and the bond isn't strong enough so the bond breaks and so ends the vacuum. That leaves the ball behind. Some of the water shoots up and some of the water rolls with the ball. The ball would fall at this point but because more water is hitting the ball, the process restarts.

In conclusion, there is no other force beyond water pushing into the ball and then water pulling on the ball as it tries to carry it with it. There is no other force pushing the ball back to the center again. The cause for reset is 100% the vacuum.

Where you are mentioning Bernoulli effect, shouldn't that be the Coanda effect? Bernoulli effect is only relevant with a single stream. As soon as you split the stream up it is no longer relevant.
With a single stream, if you speed up the stream at a particular point then the pressure must go down--in fluid dynamics, acceleration is always from a region of high pressure to a region of low pressure.
With two separate streams it is possible to have higher pressure with a faster stream because the connection between the streams is broken.
With an airfoil the lift is generated with a combination of the Coanda effect plus the third law of motion. With this demonstration the "lift" is cause by a combination of surface tension, or adhesion, and the third law of motion.

i think it might be more similar to that bernoulli effect you mentioned than you allude to:
when the styrofoam is on the very edge of the water, the ball pushes the water out SLIGHTLY, but because water is a much denser medium the "lift" produced will still exert a net force that pushes the ball into the stream (even though the stream is interrupted),
when it gets too far into the stream, however, the ball "stalls" and the lifting force gets turned into drag, which pushes the ball back out of the stream,

the water that whips around the ball has lost most of it's kinetic (upward) energy and is mainly "dragged along" due to angular momentum and surface tension, and only exerts very little force (if any) compared to the other forces at play (it's also kinda visible at 3:48, where there's hardly any water whipping around the ball, yet the ball still gets "sucked" into the stream)

the point at which it stabilises is where lift and drag cancel out,

now i do agree it's different from the ping-pong ball because there's no flow on the "back" edge of the sphere/cylinder, but they're likely still the same forces at work, and i wouldn't be surprised if this was possible with laminar flow on a larger sphere relative to the flow source

The same physics phenomenon can be investigated (and I happened to investigate it for a full week only 3 weeks back) when one puts say a ball in water with a constant stream flowing onto it. However the concept of the ball flinging the fluid away from the stream, thus moving back, does not work; the ball cannot fling water under itself... from what my group could come up in a week was that the main restoring force is due to pressure differences between the movi fluid on one side of the ball, and the absence of a moving fluid on the other side. I disagree about how it levitates. You were on the right track when you explained the ping pong ball and hair dryer. If you notice the larger ball in the water stream is not throwing very much of the water over the top and down, most of the water is actually being thrown upward. In fact, in slow motion upon releasing the ball from your hand the ball begins to lift, even before any water at all has been thrown downward, before the rotation has been established.The rotation does give it a gryoscopic stability. But the two forces that hold it up are the impingement of the water stream, that is the mass of water giving it an upward reaction, and this also keeps the ball from moving too far into the stream. The water is also moving fast and gives it a low pressure, causing it to cling to the stream. So it's a high pressure underneath the ball combined with a low pressure on the side of the ball that keeps it stable. Gryoscopic effect eventually adds some stability. I don't see enough mass of water moving downward to provide the thrust needed to levitate it, it's not even enough to counter the larger mass being thrown upward, and certainly no upward thrust at all  before the ball is spinning up to speed.

The force of the spray down cannot equal the force of the water out, the system momentum has to be equal and the sprays in all directions put pay to this theory. In addition this would have no affect on the initial suction of the ball prior to the spin being induced. The actual explanation comes from a common misconception about the lift from airflow being from bernoulli's principle alone. In actual fact a large force comes from the coanda effect, which is the suction caused by the boundary layer on the surface in the flow. If you dangle a spoon from a string and bring the curve under a stream of water under a tap you can see this effect yourself, noting how its not the pressure differential of the two sides of the spoon causing the spoons displacement. This demonstration of the ball in water is much the same. Its the suction of the boundary layer caused by the coanda effect, not the countering momentum of the water droplets, which itself would be minimal. This also helps to explain the natural balancing to bring the ball back into the stream as the effect is exasperated by increased deflection of the boundary until the point boundary separates from the surface and the ball falls from the stream.

I believe apart from the force mentioned, or instead of, some or all these forces are helping maintain the equilibrium and keeping the disc up:

(1) water is not hitting the ball/disc exactly on the circumference. It's slightly inside. That force breaks down into two components: (a) rotate the ball/disc (b) apply upward force which helps counteract gravity.

(2) gyroscope effect for position stability

(3) Bernoulli effect and Magnus effect for the horizontal force to keep it in the stream

(4) stickiness to water which applies an upward force as the water is shooting upwards, helping counteract gravity.

+veritasium , I'm not sure if the explanation in the video is properly adressing the physics behind the effect, what do you think of the following following?

I think the system works like this:
- The water hits the ball (putting forces of momentum on the ball as described by Derek), but also overruling the vanderwaal’s forces of the waterdrops on micro-level, making the water ‘sticking’ to the ball.
- We see water leaving the ball as it rotates.
- So the mass attached to the ball by surface-tension (vanderwaals forces), decreases as a function of the angle (theta) and the rotational velocity (omega). (Differential equilibrium).
{Vanderwaalsforces < m*r*omega^2 --> m_dot (massflow)}
- The distribution of the water over the ball is significant in respect to the low mass ball.
- Radially the mass moment of inertia of the ball is distributed eccentrically in respect to the center of mass of the ball (the rotation point of the ball), by the mass leaving the ball (imagine the leaving droplets 'pulling' the ball, (local/micro level))
Visualize the ball’s wall is always thicker on the side of the beam (system level).
- The sum of the centripetal forces on the side of the beam(collocated-side) > (non-collocated side). The separation of the contribution is located at the center of the ball, which is its turning point.
- The equilibrium exists as follows:

{ Forces of momentum of waterbeam (as function of eccentricity) } + { non-collocated centripetal forces of the water established by vanderwaals forces } = { Collocated centripetal forces of the water established by vanderwaals forces }

Actually part, of the reason is The Coanda effect in that fluids like "air" and water stick to curved surfaces. The reason why the ball remains touching the stream is that the water sticks to the balls curvature and not only remains touching the stream, but rotates it. This is also why the pressure of the stream has to be great enough to hold the weight of the ball so that it can stick on to it. The stuff Vertasium said is probably also present and true but in small factors (the opposing force from the water to the ball is probably not great enough based on acceleration and mass to hold it in equilibrium).

Interesting explanation. Care to discuss?
My first thought was along the lines of water surface tension between the upward stream and the layer of water on the ball that would act to tug the ball upward with the stream. (thinking out loud) If you set up the stream on your left and ball on your right, then the majority of the water will be impacting on the left face of the ball and flinging off in the upper-left quadrant. Thinking that the water flinging off would impart a tug to the upper-left as the water layer on the ball tries to maintain that surface tension. That up/left force (together a few more nuanced forces at play) need only be strong enough to counter gravity and the right-ward impact force from the stream to maintain a general equilibrium. The effective center of mass would also move toward the left face where most of the water is collected, so I'd imagine there are other interesting effects at play here.

Also thinking that by the time the water has reached the far side of the ball it'd have lost too much momentum (maybe not the correct quality) to be useful for pushing off of. The video even shows at 3:45 that the ball is starting to lift up before the water begins flinging off the lower-right quadrant. It even gets pulled left into the stream first (assuming he didn't impart any force himself) though I'm not as confident in my reasoning on that part.

Final thought: if the water pushing off the far side were enough to lift the ball, could you replicate the effect with a small water stream directly under the ball to demonstrate how much upward force it'd take to lift the ball?

I had some confusion about his explanation after watching, so i will explain what causes this effect.

The effect is due two an equilibrium of these two phases:
A) The ball adheres to the water, and uses its torque to force the adhered water downward and away from the stream. This causes the ball to go the opposite direction of expelled water; upward and into the stream.

B) As it enters the stream or expels the water, the torque decreases, and the ball stops moving up and into the stream. The ball then is touching the water at the most outer point on the ball that is perpendicular to the ground, on the side of the stream.

The end of phase B actually increases torque and adhesion, which makes the ball move into the stream as the expulsion of water increases. (edit) This is where phase A begins.

I'm not as smart as you nor do I have the physics background so take this with a grain of salt... but... just looking at it, I would think it has more to do with the rotational center of mass being changed by the water.  That is,  due to the fact that the water clings most in the quadrant of the ball immediately after where the stream hits, the ball is heavier in that quadrant.  That brings the ball's center of mass inward toward the water stream which make the ball rotate around a center that is slightly toward the stream of water.  If you think about it, that will cause the ball to rotate around an axis that pushes it in toward the stream of water.  This naturally balances in a feedback loop.  If you look at the slo-mo, you can see the ball "wobbling" from the off-center center of mass.
